prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
This science goal aims at detecting CO(3-2) line from galaxies at z=1.4. With C34-4 configuration in band-4, the angular resolution is 0.74", which is comparable to the angular resolution of CO(5-4) observation with ALMA cycle0.
The mean flux density of CO(5-4) is 2 mJy from our stacking analysis. If we assume CO J-ladder for color selected galaxies such as sBzK galaxies at z=1-2, the expected CO(3-2) flux density is 1 mJy. An individual molecular cloud is presumably regarded to be a point source, because the expected intrinsic size is likely to be small enough as compared with the beam size of 0.74‚Äù (~6 kpc). Then the peak surface brightness is 1 mJy/beam. To detect this emission with S/N of 5 in 200 km/s bin (average value of CO(3-2) line width by Tacconi et al. 2013), required sensitivity is 0.2 mJy/beam and the on-source time is 25.46 minutes for one target. We have 6 targets with this spectral setup, and a total observing time from OT is 5.29 hours including overheads. Note that the velocity width of the stacked CO(5-4) is about 350 km/s, but this includes uncertainty of redshift zero point from NIR spectroscopy as well as motion in a galaxy potential. Thus supposing 350 km/s velocity width would not be reasonable. We set baseband-3 and 4 on the similar frequency of baseband-1 and 2 for covering wider velocity range.

This science goal aims at investigating the internal structure of galaxies at z=1.4 with dust emission. With C34-5 configuration in band-7, the angular resolution is 0.22" (~2kpc), which is similar to the typical size of clump seen in star-forming galaxies at the redshift.
As described in Scientific Justification, the continuum emission in band-6 is 0.2 mJy for 'massive high metallicity galaxy sample'. With this data and Herschel data, we obtained dust temperature of 36 K and beta of 1.6 by fitting the modified blackbody function on the FIR data. The expected continuum emission can be calculated from the averaged continuum flux density in band-6 and continuum slope. The resulting expected continuum emission is 0.7 mJy. In the proposed observations, the internal structure of galaxies may be resolved and we should expect the fainter surface brightness. We suppose this emission comes from separate two clumps and each clump has 2 kpc size. Then, the surface brightness would be 0.25 mJy/beam with 0.22" angular resolution similar to the clump size. To detect this emission with S/N of 5 with using 4 spectral windows (total width 7.5 GHz), required sensitivity is 0.05 mJy/beam and the on-source time is 19.44 minutes for one target. We have 6 targets with this spectral setup, and a total observing time from OT is 4.53 hours including overheads.
We select the spectral line mode for dust continuum observation, because we can remove some lines which come to the frequency serendipitously. Thus, the peak line flux density per beam and line width in this science goal are any values to avoid the error in validation.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The knowledge on physical properties of ISM in high redshift galaxies is necessary for the understanding of the galaxy formation and evolution. In ALMA cycle0, we observed CO(5-4) and dust thermal emission in band-6 from 20 star-forming galaxies on the main sequence at z=1.4. Stacking analysis of the ALMA and Herschel data enabled us to know the 'average' luminosity density of CO(5-4) line thus molecular gas mass, and dust temperature, emissivity, and dust-to-gas ratio. In this proposal, we propose the observations of CO(3-2) in band-4 and dust thermal emission in band-7 toward 6 massive and high metallicity star-forming galaxies among cycle0 targets. The metallicity of the galaxies is determined by near-infrared spectroscopy. The aims of this observations are to know physical parameters of ISM such as molecular gas mass, molecular gas density, dust mass, distribution of dust (hence of molecular gas) in the galaxies, and dust-to-gas ratio for ‚Äòindividual‚Äô star-forming galaxies on the main sequence at z=1.4. We also examine relations among these quantities and compare with those in local main sequence star-forming galaxies as well as ULIRGS in lower redshifts.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00648.S, "Molecular gas/dust and gas metallicity in star-forming galaxies at z~1.4", Kouji OHTA
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Graduate School of Science, Kyoto University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Optical and Infrared Astronomy, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Graduate School of Science, Kyoto University
Hawaii Observatory (Subaru Telescope), National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe, The University of Tokyo
